prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 HCN(1-0), HCO(1-0), CS(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We require mapping of the emission of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0) and CS(2-1) with a ~0.5"(~35 pc) spatial resolution in Band 3 using one single pointing. These maps will be combined with the Cycle 0 ALMA maps obtained for the mid-J transitions of the same species at the same spatial resolution. These high-resolution data will allow us to characterize the changes in the excitation and chemistry of the dense molecular gas on the critical scales (35--40pc) inside the CND. The observations we request in Band 3 will include, as a bonus, SiO (2-1), as well as isotopologues of the HCN(1-0) and the HCO+(1-0).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Three of our basebands will be centered around the HCO+(1-0), HCN(1-0) and CS(2-1) which are our main target transitions. The frequencies have been chosen so that to optimize also observations of H13CO+(1-0), H13CN(1-0), SiO(2-1) and SO (5-4). We note that these lines are not driving our sensitivity calculation at all, and are included for the sake of serendipity.
The bandwidth used for the sensitivity calculation is 12 km/s. We nevertheless ask for a factor 2 finer spectral resolution to ensure that the GMCs will be spectroscopically resolved in the CND.

We require a 0.5" (=35 pc) spatial resolution in order to be able to combine the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0) and the CS (2-1) Band 3 data with Cycle 0 mid-J lines of the same species at the same spatial resolution. In Viti et al (2014) we showed that ALMA data from cycle 0 at 0.5" alone were not sufficient in order to fully constrain the physical characteristics of the individual sub-regions and that we needed more transitions of the same species at the same spatial resolution.
We require a LAS ~5", based on the source size and velocity structure derived from the CO(3-2) channel maps analyzed in Garcia-Burillo et al 2014.

The expected fluxes for the relevant lines of this proposal (HCN1-0, HCO+1-0 and CS2-1) have been securely estimated based on the already existent maps of the CND of NGC1068 for both mid-J (with ALMA) and low-J (with PdBI). In more details, we use the HCO+ transitions in the AGN knot as representative of the position inside the CND where the emission is the weakest in most of the tracers, to account for the worst case scenario, and assure that throughout the CND and the SB ring the lines will be securely mapped. We illustrate that the AGN-knot is where the CO3-2 is the weakest in Fig.1 and Table 1.
Following this approach, we find that HCO+(4-3)/HCO+(1-0) ~ 0.5 at the AGN position; from ALMA Cycle 0 data we have a peak flux for the HCO+(4-3) of 24 mJy. Hence the peak flux for the 1-0 should be around 3 mJy at the AGN. With a 1-sigma=0.6mJy/beam in 12 km/s-channels we estimate that the maps will have a dynamic range >5 for HCO+(1-0) per 12km/s-channel at the AGN knot; this translates into a S/N ratio >10 for 1/3 of the line. The corresponding numbers for HCN are more favourable. As mentioned above, HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0) and CS(2-1) lines will be mapped with higher S/N ratios elsewhere in the CND and in the SB ring, as these regions are characterized by stronger mid-J fluxes and/or significantly lower mid-J/low-J ratios, respectively. In the chosen set-up we will also obtain the SiO(2-1) line; for this transition we can estimate its flux from the PdBI data in Garcia-Burillo et al. (2010). From these data the peak flux in the whole CND is 13.5mJy with a beam of 3"; so we expect around 2.3mJy per 0.5 beam. Hence the SiO(2-1) wil be detected with S/N > 4.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 4 CS(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science Goal description is the same as the one for Science goal 3:
We require mapping at 0.5" spatial resolution of the CS3-2, which, in conjunction with existing data and the CS(6-5) from Science goal 3, will be used to construct the CS ladder for each sub-region (~35") of the CND.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The first of our baseband is centered in the transition that we are interested in, the CS(4-3). The other three basebands are configured to cover the transitions of the strongest CH3OH J=3-2 ladder, c-C3H2 (4,4-4,1) and SO (4-3). We note that these serendipitous lines are not driving our sensitivity calculations.

The justification for the requirement for the angular resolution and LAS is as for Science goal I. We need to combine these data with the data from cycle 0 which were at 0.5" resolution. The LAS is derived from the analysis of CO(3-2) channel maps of cycle 0.

We adopt the same approach as for science goal I, i.e., we use the AGN-knot as representative of the worst-case scenario (weakest emission in the CND) to assure that mapping is feasible elsewhere/throughout in the CND.
The CS3-2 peak flux at the AGN-knot has been estimated using the following procedure: we have the CS7-6 flux from the ALMA data (2mJy at the AGN position); we also know the CS7-6/2-1 ratio (where the data for the 2-1 come from the PdB - see Viti et al. 2014) which is ~0.4. We then ran a small grid of RADEX models to determine the CS7-6/CS3-2 on the basis of the two ratios above. We therefore estimate a CS 3-2 peak flux of ~2mJy. With a 0.5 mJy sensitivity per beam in 12 kms-1 channels we will get a S/N >4-per 12 km/s-channel for this line, and a corresponding S/N >= 8 over 1/3 of the line width. We foresee a significantly higher dynamic range elsewhere in the CND and the SB ring. We do not have PdB data for the methanol lines that come as a bonus; however we can estimate its flux from single dish data from Garcia-Burillo et al. (2010): they find a peak flux of ~50mJy in 17" beam; we can therefore expect a peak flux of 1.4 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 CS(6-5)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science Goal description is the same as the one for Science goal 2:
We require mapping at 0.5" spatial resolution of the CS6-5, which, in conjunction existing data and the CS(3-2) from Science goal 2, will be used to construct the CS ladder for each sub-region (~35") of the CND.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this spectral set up we center our first Baseband on the CS(6-5) line, which is the main science target. The other basebands will cover SiO(7-6), CH3OH (2-2) and H2CO (4-3). The SiO (7-6) line (and the SiO (2-1) from Science Goal 2) will be combined with SiO maps of 5-4 and 6-5 from Cycle 2 which, if taken, will be available to our team. Note however that these extra transitions are not driving the sensitivity calculation.

Similar to those of science goals I-II.
We need to reach 0.5 " spatial resolution for the sake of comparison with cycle 0 maps in order to obtain line ratios at a common spatial resolution of 35 pc.
The LAS requirement of 5" is derived from the detailed analysis of vel. channel maps of cycle 0.

We adopt the same approach as for science goals-I, II, regarding the choice of the AGN-knot as representative of the worst-case scenario for mapping throughout the CND.
The CS 6-5 peak flux has been estimated using the following procedure: we have the CS7-6 flux from Cycle 0 (2mJy at the AGN position); we also know the CS7-6/2-1 ratio (where the data for the 2-1 are PdBI) which is ~0.4. We then ran a small grid of RADEX models to determine the CS7-6/CS6-5 ratio on the basis of the two ratios above. We find a peak flux of ~2.5. With a 0.7 mJy per beam in 12 kms-1 channels we estimate a dynamic range of > 3.5 for this transition, and a corresponding S/N ratio > 7.3 over 1/3 of the line-width. We foresee significantly higher S/N ratios elsewhere in the CND. The SiO (7-6) comes as a bonus; nevertheless we can estimate an approximate peak flux by using the SiO(2-1) estimate from Science Goal 1 and a small grid of RADEX models (ran with physical conditions as derived in NGC1068 CND from Viti et al. 2014). We find a conservative value of 0.5 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the emission of the dense molecular tracers (HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), CS(2-1)) in Band 3, as well as CS (4-3) in Band 4, and CS (6-5) in Band 7, in NGC1068 at the resolution of 0.5". We have two immediate goals: (1) characterize the changes in the excitation and chemistry of the dense molecular gas on the critical scales (35-40pc) inside the circumnuclear disk (CND); (2) trace and characterize the shock component(s) within the CND and link their chemistry to the dynamics of the AGN-driven outflow. The case of this project builds on the results of our succesful Cycle 0 project, where we mapped at high resolution HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and CS(7-6): these data have revealed the presence of 5 chemically distinct sub-regions within the CND. Analyses of the data (Viti et al. 2014) revealed a pronounced chemical differentiation across the CND and hinted at the presence of a three-phase ISM within each sub-region. We request a second, low J, transition of each species to determine the chemical and physical characteristics of each sub-region within the CND, and two more transitions of CS in order to relate the shock-driven chemistry to the molecular outflow driven by the AGN.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: "Probing the feeding/feeback budget in NGC1068 on a ~few pc scales", PI: Garcia-Burillo, id: 2015.1.00163.S
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 0 (2011.0.00083.S), PI: Garcia-Burillo; title "The footprints of SF and AGN activity in NGC1068: a case study for ALMA" Cycle 2(2013.1.00055.S) - PI: Garcia-Burillo: title "The footprints of SF and AGN activity in NGC1068 (II)"; not observed at the time of submission of cycle 3
